```python3
           except (Timeout, ConnectionError):

Unfortunately, **we are unable to accept this pull request until this situation is corrected.**

Here are your options:

1. If you had an email address set for the commit that simply wasn't linked to your GitHub account you can link that email now and it will retroactively apply to your commits. The simplest way to do this is to click the link to one of the above commits and look for a blue question mark in a blue circle in the top left. Hovering over that bubble will show you what email address you used. Clicking on that button will take you to your email address settings on GitHub. Just add the email address on that page and you're all set. GitHub has more information about this option [in their help center](https://help.github.com/articles/setting-your-email-in-git/#commits-on-github-arent-linking-to-my-account).

2. If you didn't use an email address at all, it was an invalid email, or it's one you can't link to your GitHub, you will need to change the authorship information of the commit and your global Git settings so this doesn't happen again going forward. GitHub provides some great instructions on how to change your authorship information [in their help center](https://help.github.com/articles/setting-your-email-in-git/).
   * If you only made a single commit you should be able to run
      ```
      git commit --amend --author="Author Name <email@address.com>"
      ```
      (substituting Author Name and email@address.com for your actual information) to set the authorship information.
   * If you made more than one commit and the commit with the missing authorship information is not the most recent one you have two options:
       1. You can re-create all commits missing authorship information. This is going to be the easiest solution for developers that aren't extremely confident in their Git and command line skills.
       2. You can use [this script](https://help.github.com/articles/changing-author-info/) that GitHub provides to rewrite history. **Please note:** this should be used only if you are very confident in your abilities and understand its impacts.
   * Whichever method you choose, I will come by to re-check the pull request once you push the fixes to this branch.

We apologize for this inconvenience, especially since it usually bites new contributors to Home Assistant. We hope you understand the need for us to protect ourselves and the great community we all have built legally. The best thing to come out of this is that you only need to fix this once and it benefits the entire Home Assistant and GitHub community.

Thanks, I look forward to checking this PR again soon! :heart:

Comment:
I think you got the description mostly correct.

async_unload_entry will be called of you ask to reload or disable a config entry. It should first ask all platforms (cover, switch, ...) to unload (which will remove all entites, calling the will remove callback on all entities registered on that config entry and platform). Once that is complete, the integration async_unload_entry will (should) continue to disconnect any connections and remnant state of the integration.

It should be done in this order to avoid any entities being dependent on unloaded global state/connections.

Comment: Just don't catch it.
Author: ivgg-me

Comment:
> Why can't a hostname be used?

Because the device tells me only the IP address. See also the [Remootio Websocket API documentation](https://github.com/remootio/remootio-api-documentation), e.g. the [newest version (v3)](https://github.com/remootio/remootio-api-documentation/blob/master/websocket_api_v3_specification.md) of it.
Author: ivgg-me

Comment:
> This overwrite any required field invalid errors from above.

This is intentional, because the device can also be discovered using zeroconf, but this will be implemented in a later version of the integration.

If the device is discovered using zeroconf, only the IP address is known first, the other data (API Secret Key and API Auth Key) must be given by the user. The idea was that in this case only the error message _Please complete the setup of your Remootio device._ with key `user_input_incomplete` would be presented to the user.
Author: ivgg-me

Comment:
> Don't abreviate. Write it out in full.

The constant `CONF_API_SECRET_KEY` is used in the voluptuous schema based on which the form for configuring the integration is presented to the user. When I write it out in full, a password field for the _API Secret Key_ is displayed on the form, but a simple text field for the _API Auth Key_, which I didn't want.
Author: ivgg-me

Comment:
> you should set up the connection in the **init**.py file. Otherwise it will end up harder to add other entity types.

I implemented this because, according to the [documentation](https://github.com/remootio/remootio-api-documentation/blob/master/websocket_api_v3_specification.md), the device automatically closes an unauthenticated session after 30 seconds.

In the method `utils.create_client` an instance of the `RemootioClient` class is instantiated, whereby a connection to the device is also established and, among other things, the authentication takes place. - The library [_aioremootio_](https://pypi.org/project/aioremootio/), which contains the class `RemootioClient`, was also written by me.
Author: ivgg-me

Comment:
> This should really be converted to DataUpdateCoordinator. With CoordinatorEntity entities. This will schedule there own update once the coordinator updates.

I don't understand why I should use a DataUpdateCoordinator here?

After a time that can be configured via the Remootio app, the device triggers a `LEFT_OPEN` event if the controlled garage door or garden gate has been left open. This event is received by the `RemootioClient` and calls the listener `RemootioCoverEventListener` for it, which in turn triggers a `remootio_left_open` Home Assistant event.
Author: ivgg-me

Comment: I use this method both in the method `utils.get_serial_number` and the method `utils.create_client` to translate exceptions of the library into Home Assistant exceptions.
Author: ivgg-me

Comment: The error `UnsupportedRemootioApiVersionError` is an exception of the integration raised by the method `utils._check_api_version`, the `RemootioClient` can throw some other exceptions from the library (which also contains the `RemootioClient`) that I handle in the method `utils._handle_exception`.
Author: ivgg-me

Comment: A hostname for any IP address can be set on your DNS server/router. Advanced users might want to do that to keep control of their systems.
Author: ivgg-me

Comment: Seems a bit confusing. You can have different flows.
Author: ivgg-me

Comment: I'm not saying your solution doesnt work. But you add boilerplate signalling that the update coordinator reduces.
Author: ivgg-me

Comment: The exceptions you translate into, are mostly example exceptions. They serve no meaning outside your config flow. As such, it is better to propagate the original exception

Comment:
> That can happen, please do not ping for reviews, especially since well, some people celebrate Christmas with their families now as well.

First of all I do understand it's Christmas right now and I don't expect an immediate review. You can tell that since I've waited over two months without pinging anyone.
Please, don't use such a convenient excuse for not reviewing something when there's proof all over HA that some contributions take insane amounts of time to be reviewed... Specially since well, you're using the fact that it's Christams to make me the bad guy here and that's not fair...

Anyway, I'll wait without pinging anyone or eventually close this since apparently only contributions made by the core members of this project are reviewed/merged in a reasonable time, as opposed to contributions made by third parties, which  can be delayed forever if none reviews them...
Author: Noltari

Comment:
That is true, core contributors are often faster reviewed. This is normal. 

Pinging (and thus slightly demanding) reviews, is not accepted. This is not an excuse; but policy. Please respect that. 

Contributing is not just opening PR, is it also reviewing. Feel free to help out doing that so the queue becomes smaller. Looking forward for you to help out.

PS: Me personally skips PRs that ask for reviews, because I don't want it to work like that.
Author: Noltari

Author: fwestenberg

Comment:
This explanation makes no sense. If the device can't be reached, because it's unplugged, or because the user has flicked a physical on/off switch, it should be set to unavailable.

State off should be used if it's possible to call the `turn_on` service to turn the speaker on.

It seems to me like there's a bug related to handling errors which you need to fix. If Home Assistant loses connection to the speaker for whatever reason, Home Assistant should always automatically reconnect without user intervention such as reloading the config entry.
Author: fwestenberg

Comment: Instead of this, in particular because it's mentioned that there are issues related to reconnecting to the speaker, please look into the [data update coordinator](https://developers.home-assistant.io/docs/integration_fetching_data/#coordinated-single-api-poll-for-data-for-all-entities) which helps a great deal with error handling.
Author: fwestenberg

Comment:
It doesn't need to happen in __init__, it can happen in update:
```py
    async def async_update(self) -> None:
        """Get the latest details from the device."""
        await self._client.async_update()
        self._attr_media_album_name = self._client.media_album_name
        ...
```

This reduces the line count a great deal, which is a good thing

Comment:
I see, but we should not work around typing issues by changing the code.
Instead, do something like this:
```py
assert entry.unique_id
self._attr_unique_id = entry.unique_id
```

Or just cast to a str
```py
self._attr_unique_id = cast(str, entry.unique_id)
```
Author: fwestenberg

Comment: Casting fixed this indeed. Thanks!
Author: fwestenberg

Comment: This 5s poll time is mainly to refresh the attributes: volume, position etc. while playing. The Devialet API seems to get a push mechanism someday, but until that is implemented this seems the easiest way.

Comment: I incorporated @bdraco 's suggestions and added an extra verification to determine that the correct connection was made. I changed the way entities are registered. Previously it would register all possible entities and disable the ones that are not usable. Now I only register usable entities. This makes the end-user experience better because the user's screen isn't populated with 18 different entities when most likely they would only use 6 of them.
Author: ssaenger

Comment:
- Incorporated @bdraco 's suggestions.
- Increased poll time from 10 (default) to 30 seconds. I felt like 10 seconds is too fast to poll the state, and if user makes a change to a zone in home assistant, the amp state is updated immediately.
- Set default zone names. If this was not done, user would not be able to select zones until user configured it through an options flow.
- Disable polling and set device state to unavailable if amplifier turns off at anytime. This is to prevent logs from filling with error messages, and to save on resources.
Author: ssaenger

Comment: Incorporated @bdraco suggestions.
Author: ssaenger

Comment:
Added coordinator to retrieve data and update my entities. I call `self.schedule_update_ha_state(True)` when a service is called (such as "set volume") to tell HA to pull data from the WS66i amp in order to update my states. However, sometimes there is a big delay between when `self.schedule_update_ha_state(True)` is called and when data is pulled, so there are times where there is a big delay from when the user changes a state to when lovelace updates the state. It seems like HA is throttling my calls to `self.schedule_update_ha_state(True)`. Unfortunately this makes for a bad user experience.

I still need to test shutting off my amp while integration is active...

Edit: Maybe I can bypass the coordinator and have my entity update its own state and alert HA that state was changed. This way I can avoid the long delays with `self.schedule_update_ha_state(True)`.
Author: ssaenger

Comment:
I am confident that commands sent off to the WS66i amp will be accepted, so my entity class will update its state and alert HA by calling `self.async_write_ha_state()`. This will provide immediate feedback to the end-user, and won't poll the amp each time the user makes a change through HA.

Since pyws66i returns a ZoneStatus class, my entities will reference that instead of copying those values locally. This means I brought back some `@property` attributes as they will need to read from the ZoneStatus class.

I've added coordinator handling to close the WS66i connection if the data pipeline breaks (such as the amp powered off) and on subsequent coordinator updates, it will retry to establish a connection.

I made the fields in the options flow required. If the user were to not provide a value in a config flow, that user would not be able to select a source through HA. This is undesired and required additional error checking in a few other places. This is especially problematic if the user selected a source via the keypad that wasn't configured in the config flow. By making them mandatory, the user has the freedom to select all available sources and some error checking was no longer needed, simplifying code.
Author: ssaenger

Comment: I tried making the restore service more robust by remembering what the snapshot status was between HA restarts, however the data in `hass.data` is wiped out between restarts. Is there any place to store data persistently for integrations?
Author: ssaenger

Comment:
> I tried making the restore service more robust by remembering what the snapshot status was between HA restarts, however the data in `hass.data` is wiped out between restarts. Is there any place to store data persistently for integrations?

 I suggest removing the services for now and working through them in a followup PR. 

https://developers.home-assistant.io/docs/creating_component_code_review?_highlight=small&_highlight=pos#5-make-your-pull-request-as-small-as-possible
Author: ssaenger

Comment:
Sorry, I was getting ahead of myself. I was trying to continue to make improvements during a PR and that just makes it more difficult for you, the reviewer.

About custom services, these services should stay however; they are vital components to the integration. A basic automation will, for example, listen for an event, such as a doorbell rang event, snapshot the zones, play a notification indicating someone is at the door, and then restore the zones. In this use case, the snapshot will no longer be needed because a new snapshot will be taken whenever a notification needs to be played. Come to think of it, snapshots don't need to be in non-volatile memory at all.

I won't be making any more changes. In a future PR, I'll look into discovery. I hope this is acceptable.
Author: ssaenger

Comment:
@bdraco OK, I did the math.  Excluding tests and non-Python code, this integration adds 1280 lines of code, and a substantial amount of that is just boilerplate required to fit the HASS standards (378 lines alone are in config flow dot py).  I am not sure how I would go about making it any smaller tho — this is the bare minimum for the stated functionality (play / pause / stop / next / previous / play head position).

Of course, I am open to suggestions!
Author: Rudd-O

Comment:
there are a couple of options you can do:
1. the most straightforward is to think of some initial, limited functionality in the first PR, then add the additional ones in future PRs. Surely, there is a partial usage that will already give some, although not all, of the value. This will likely reduce your config_flow and other hass parts that will be deferred to the next PRs. Once you have the framework with minimum functionality, adding the additional ones will require smaller PRs that will get faster reviews
2. If the absolute MVP still requires a large amount of code, they have options to set a side branch, which can have multiple PRs. Each one can be small and implement a part, and it will only be released when you feel it is ready.

When I released the Dynalite integration, initially it only had lights, which is very limited. Switches, blinds, and other functionality was added in later PRs. When working on the first one, I learned some of their coding standards and built a good alignment with the reviewer, so the future ones were much quicker.
Author: Rudd-O

Comment:
The thing is, this code (casting certs and keys from bytes to objects) is _only_ needed because HASS insists on storing strings / bytes -- the integration only deals in actual typed Python objects, like `Certificate` and `Key`.  Short of moving these casting functions into helpers within the client, this actually belongs here and not in the MPRIS client.  All of the logic of actually obtaining the certificate and pairing with the remote end is fully sealed up in the MPRIS client.

What should I do?  I'm 100% new to writing HASS code, I need your help.  Thanks in advance.
Author: Rudd-O

Comment:
While we want to store configuration data in the config entry, certificates are a bit large to put in there since everything has to be serialized to JSON and back.  Config entry storage isn't a database so every time its loaded/saved all the data for all the config entries has to be processed.

You can storage large data in `.storage`

You can accomplish this in two different ways.

You can pass the storage path to the library with `hass.config.path`. `git grep` for a few examples in the code base, and let it be responsible for reading the certificates from disk (in the executor please!)

Also you can use `homeassistant.helpers.storage` to store the certificates.  There is an example in `homekit` for aid storage.

I almost always prefer the solution that has the least code in HA itself and offloads that to the PyPI package code since it reduces the review time to make changes to an integration and keeps things moving along.
Author: Rudd-O

Comment: Roger that.  The client module has no provision to store anything on disk -- it is stateless -- so I will factor out the certificate load / save code to their own separate functions and proceed as you advised with regards to mirroring what `homekit` does.
Author: Rudd-O

Comment:
@davet2001 Thanks for taking the time!

Here is a diff of just the changes to this integration I've made: https://gist.github.com/02JanDal/7c0d50e191e6bc74422a6c81ac6e1282
Note that it excludes changes in generated files like requirements and CODEOWNERS, as those also include changes from other commits so are harder for me to isolate.

The file with the most significant changes is [`__init__.py`](https://gist.github.com/02JanDal/7c0d50e191e6bc74422a6c81ac6e1282#file-sungrow-diff-L1-L284), as my library is async (although not 100% until HA switches to pymodbus 3 but that has to wait for upstream and the modbus integration) I had to move some stuff out of the SungrowData constructor into `async_setup_entry`. It also contains some aspects in `SungrowCoordinatorEntity` previously found in `sensor.py`, which is mostly just a preparation for more entity types (which I've got ready locally but will be part of a future PR).

[`config_flow.py`](https://gist.github.com/02JanDal/7c0d50e191e6bc74422a6c81ac6e1282#file-sungrow-diff-L285-L368) should be functionally equivalent.

[`const.py`](https://gist.github.com/02JanDal/7c0d50e191e6bc74422a6c81ac6e1282#file-sungrow-diff-L369-L588) lost the sensor definitions, I moved them into `sensor.py`, again as it makes more sense to me once more entity types are there.

[`sensor.py`](https://gist.github.com/02JanDal/7c0d50e191e6bc74422a6c81ac6e1282#file-sungrow-diff-L608-L1075) gained the sensor definitions, quite a few more as my library supports more, while also losing some details in them (like device class and unit) that I instead compute inside of `SungrowCoordinatorEntity` based on the metadata in `pysungrow`.

In the tests the changes are almost exclusively about changing what is mocked, I did however introduce a [fixture](https://gist.github.com/02JanDal/7c0d50e191e6bc74422a6c81ac6e1282#file-sungrow-diff-L1207-L1231) that takes care of the patching that is done for most tests, as well as creating and registering the config entry.

Other than that it's of course quite a few import changes, as well as some adaptions to changes in the HA API, like using `SensorDeviceClass` instead of strings and going from `async_setup_platforms` to `async_forward_entry_setups`.

Comment:
Hi @Vaskivskyi,

In general, the hass team avoids multiple integrations. (Difficult to maintain and support)

They will most likely ask you to rebase on the existing integration. I know it's effort but it's possible to make it work with both the HTTP API as well as SSL (for legacy devices - don't know if it's worth keeping for a hand full of old devices though.).

Just my 2c.
Author: Vaskivskyi

Comment:
> Hi @Vaskivskyi,
> 
> In general, the hass team avoids multiple integrations. (Difficult to maintain and support)
> 
> They will most likely ask you to rebase on the existing integration. I know it's effort but it's possible to make it work with both the HTTP API as well as SSL (for legacy devices - don't know if it's worth keeping for a hand full of old devices though.).
> 
> Just my 2c.

Tbh I wouldn't agree with such an approach at all. The extra effort would be pure waste, especially since you end up cleaning up the old stuff anyway. I'd rather see a clean and fast path forward to the API version without any legacy to hold you back. I think the Z-wave JS approach was exacly that, and with good reason.

Comment:
Let me just make some consideration on this PR and all the others that involve AsusWRT integration on which I'm code owner.
Original AsusWRT integration have some issue with new Asus firmware / router, partially fixed with some improvement in original AioAsusWrt library based on telnet / ssh. Because with new firmware Asus released new API based on HTTP, new library based on new API  becomes available.

On May 2022 I created PR #71899 with the scope to extend the AsusWRT integration with the new HTTP protocol. This integration was ignored for many months by HA teams (I was thinking because it's to big), so I put that PR in draft and create the new PR #84152 with the scope to partially implement the previous one to give the ability to integrate new libraries in the original integration. In the meantime I also created a [custom integration](https://github.com/ollo69/ha_asuswrt_custom) that is a copy of the first PR and that I'm using from months without any issue.

Honestly I don't really like the idea to have 2 integrations for the same device, this will probably create a lot of confusion to the users. And the old integration cannot be simply removed, because old routers that do not implement HTTP API still need that version. 

But I really think that have new HTTP protocol available for new Asus routers is important, a well working device tracker is one of the most important part of Home Automation. So I hope that HA Teams will take one of this PRs in charge to better support one of te most used router.
Author: Vaskivskyi

Comment:
First I'd like to say that I used the HACS version of this integration and I really liked it. The config flow is one of the most complex I've seen and it provided a lot of helpful information from my router about my network.

I can't speak for this core implementation, but I had some serious performance issues with the custom component. I ended up running the profiler service in HA and it was clear it was this integration that was causing the issues, and even more clear running the profiler after disabling this integration.

I haven't had time to write up a detailed report, but I'd be happy to send over the profiler information.

Otherwise, I'd be cautious of the performance impact of this integration as it's the only integration I've ever had to disable due to performance reasons.
Author: Vaskivskyi
Vaskivskyi

Comment:
> Do I understand correctly that AsusWrt after implementing http(s) will have more or less the same capabilities as Asus Router?

Yes, it will use both old SSH library (for compatibility with old router / firmware) and HTTP for new router / firmware. I just put PR #71899 in draft because I didn't receive any feedback for long time and I completed development as custom component [here](https://github.com/ollo69/ha_asuswrt_custom), but I can reopen and complete that PR based on custom component if you think that this approach is the right one.
Author: Vaskivskyi

Comment:
I tested both custom integrations... and both work well and offer similar features. Asus Router creates more entities but the config flow is not user friendly. Hard to say which integration is better.

@ollo69 I think that splitting this change into smaller steps is much better approach. I will look at the first step #84152 this week.
Author: Vaskivskyi

Comment:
> Am I right that Asus Router integrations works with firmware 380 and newer?

Yes, that's correct. Actually it works with all the versions of Asus FW since the implementation of the native API (so, released in the last 12 or so years). This includes some of the 380.xx versions, even though not all of them

The same way I agree that having 2 integrations is not the best solution, I would like to point a problem of having a single integration with which user can have completely different set of sensors and controls depending on what they selected as a connection interface
Author: Vaskivskyi

Comment:
> First I'd like to say that I used the HACS version of this integration and I really liked it. The config flow is one of the most complex I've seen and it provided a lot of helpful information from my router about my network.
> 
> I can't speak for this core implementation, but I had some serious performance issues with the custom component. I ended up running the profiler service in HA and it was clear it was this integration that was causing the issues, and even more clear running the profiler after disabling this integration.
> 
> I haven't had time to write up a detailed report, but I'd be happy to send over the profiler information.
> 
> Otherwise, I'd be cautious of the performance impact of this integration as it's the only integration I've ever had to disable due to performance reasons.

@ScottG489, as I have asked you on the Community forum, it would be nice to get from you at least some information about the device you are using (model and FW version), as well as some other details about the device settings.

AsusWRT firmware has some problems which might provide performance issue on the integration side - e.g. with hanging the connection sessions instead of closing or reporting them.

In order to help with your issue (and any other issue with AsusRouter custom integration), I need to be able to diagnose and troubleshoot which exactly part is not working properly

Author: Vaskivskyi

Comment:
Hello and thanks for your feedback!

Yes, your suggestion is good. But this would require splitting the configuration for login/password (which will be handled by the re-auth flow and for which ConfigEntryAuthFailed can be raised properly) from the SLL / port settings as they are now.

Also, the credentials on the router do not expire as happens with some connected services and so on. The user needs to do this manually from the same menu as changing port/SSL - this was a part of the motivation to put them all together.

This can be implemented at the next step as a new feature and will help make the integration better. For now, I would prefer to keep the proposed code as small as possible, so the Core maintainers will be able to review it and approve it (if they find it correct and suitable).

Of course, if this plan is fine with you

The commented code is used to convert the whole string to a predefined unique_id form (including `description.name`)

Comment:
Hello @al-s,

When attempting to inspect the commits of your pull request for CLA signature status among all authors we encountered commit(s) which were not linked to a GitHub account, thus not allowing us to determine their status(es).

The commits that are missing a linked GitHub account are the following:

- [`a3ec34d0533836cbc129cea93741b840614b8bc9`](https://github.com/home-assistant/core/pull/66130/commits/a3ec34d0533836cbc129cea93741b840614b8bc9) - This commit has something that looks like an email address (alexs@pushok.com). Maybe try linking that to GitHub?.

Unfortunately, **we are unable to accept this pull request until this situation is corrected.**

Here are your options:

1. If you had an email address set for the commit that simply wasn't linked to your GitHub account you can link that email now and it will retroactively apply to your commits. The simplest way to do this is to click the link to one of the above commits and look for a blue question mark in a blue circle in the top left. Hovering over that bubble will show you what email address you used. Clicking on that button will take you to your email address settings on GitHub. Just add the email address on that page and you're all set. GitHub has more information about this option [in their help center](https://help.github.com/articles/setting-your-email-in-git/#commits-on-github-arent-linking-to-my-account).

2. If you didn't use an email address at all, it was an invalid email, or it's one you can't link to your GitHub, you will need to change the authorship information of the commit and your global Git settings so this doesn't happen again going forward. GitHub provides some great instructions on how to change your authorship information [in their help center](https://help.github.com/articles/setting-your-email-in-git/).
   * If you only made a single commit you should be able to run
      ```
      git commit --amend --author="Author Name <email@address.com>"
      ```
      (substituting Author Name and email@address.com for your actual information) to set the authorship information.
   * If you made more than one commit and the commit with the missing authorship information is not the most recent one you have two options:
       1. You can re-create all commits missing authorship information. This is going to be the easiest solution for developers that aren't extremely confident in their Git and command line skills.
       2. You can use [this script](https://help.github.com/articles/changing-author-info/) that GitHub provides to rewrite history. **Please note:** this should be used only if you are very confident in your abilities and understand its impacts.
   * Whichever method you choose, I will come by to re-check the pull request once you push the fixes to this branch.

We apologize for this inconvenience, especially since it usually bites new contributors to Home Assistant. We hope you understand the need for us to protect ourselves and the great community we all have built legally. The best thing to come out of this is that you only need to fix this once and it benefits the entire Home Assistant and GitHub community.

Thanks, I look forward to checking this PR again soon! :heart:
Author: al-s

Comment: Not sure about this. The [docs](https://developers.home-assistant.io/docs/network_discovery/#mdnszeroconf) say that we should add `zeroconf` to `dependencies` if we use `async_get_async_instance`. Perhaps with the `zeroconf` section, this dependency is added implicitly, but I have not found this documented in any way. However, I have noticed that most integrations specify it in `after_dependencies` (i.e. as an optional dependency), and this is more appropriate since having mDNS functionality is not an absolute requirement.

Fix the problem with the switch jumping back and forth

little bit less than what we normally need to get an updated state. So
the power switch would jump to its previous state and then immediately
return to the new state.

Author: ScottG489

Comment:
For readability I personally prefer using a sentinel value to short circuit. At least in this situation. There's less indentation and as you read the method from top to bottom there's less mental overhead since you can just forget what's above the short circuit conditional. In this situation it also reads more linearly since when running through the flow `user_input` being none is what happens first.

That said, I always thought it was pretty convoluted how flow steps were mixed like this. Now that I'm a little more familiar with the framework, I've made a refactor where the initial step is by itself. All the `user_input is None` checks kinda seem like an anti-pattern that's propagated the codebase. Then again, maybe I'm missing something!
Author: ScottG489

Comment: I ended up removing the defaulting behavior since it was only needed for the options flow so that won't be needed for now.
Author: ScottG489

Comment:
The big drawback of using a `dict` here is that you can't plainly see what information the config flow is gathering to use to create the config entry.

This could be cleaned up with a data object, but the values would still need to be initialized. In it's current state, I think there are few enough members where that abstraction isn't necessary quite yet, though.
Author: ScottG489

Comment: "API Key" and "API Token" are both preexisting naming in [`strings.json`](https://github.com/home-assistant/core/blob/5a18de67e5593cb965f3f343a0dfbbcde6b427e5/homeassistant/strings.json#L46-L47). Also "token" by itself could have other meanings, so I'd like to be explicit with what it's a token for.

ScottG489
Commit Message:
Initial Trello integration implementation

User enters credentials via config flow then selects 0-n boards they
would like to have card counts for each list on that board. There is
also an options flow where the user can add or remove boards freely.

For sensor updates, we not only use a coordinator to fetch all data at
once, we use Trello's REST API /batch endpoint to do so with a single
request. This is particularly important because of Trello's rate limits.

Author: ScottG489
Commit Message: Add tests for new Trello integration

Author: ScottG489
Commit Message:
Add module to strict typing

This also includes changes necessary to fulfill the strict-typing
requirements by adding type hints where necessary.

Author: ScottG489
Commit Message:
Remove Trello options flow and associated tests

It's extraneous for the initial PR and adds a lot of complexity. Will be
added back in a follow up PR.

Author: ScottG489
Commit Message:
Various refactoring fixes based on PR comments

- Replace member reference with new parameter to make method easier to
  reason about
- Rename flow step to better describe what it does
- last_step=True is redundant because by default the button will say
  "submit"
- Fix copy/paste problems with various docstrings
- Remove redundant TrelloEntity and move attributes to TrelloSensor
  subclass

Author: ScottG489
Commit Message:
Remove logic to set preselected boards when prompting the user

Remove logic to set a default value when presenting a list of boards to
select. There will never be preselected boards when prompting the user
to select them since the options flow has been removed.

Author: ScottG489
Commit Message:
Refactor initial config flow step to be it's own method

This separates concerns so that each flow step method is responsible for
processing one form.

Author: ScottG489
Commit Message:
Reference common string translations for config flow creds labels

Note that the "Token" label is changed to "API Token".

Author: ScottG489
Commit Message:
Rename constant USER_INPUT_BOARD_IDS to CONF_BOARD_IDS

So that we're more consistent with key names for constants

Author: ScottG489
Commit Message:
Update coordinator data every 60s

The coordinator was only updating on startup and it should be polling
for state changes.

I mistakenly thought 60s was the default when not specified.

Author: ScottG489
Commit Message:
Prompt user to select "Boards" not "Board names"

The user isn't choosing board names but rather selecting the boards
themselves they want to set up within the integration, so this wording
is more accurate.

Author: ScottG489
Commit Message:
Move helper method to be a factory class method

Move a helper method for creating a TrelloAdapter from creds to be a
factory class method instead.

Author: ScottG489
Commit Message:
Remove unused sensor update method

This method isn't needed when the native_value method is also being
used.

Author: ScottG489
Commit Message:
Set entities unavailable if there was a problem fetching their data

When there was a problem fetching data for a particular board, we had no
way to indicate to the sensors that there was a problem since we only
retained card count information in the coordinator data.

This change stores a richer set of data in the coordinator so the sensor
can mark itself as unavailable when appropriate.

- Use data from coordinator when setting up sensors rather than data
  stored in config entry. The config entry will soon be slimmed down to
  only contain configured board ids

Author: ScottG489
Commit Message:
Change friendly name of list entity when changed in remote source

If the name of a Trello list was updated in Trello itself, we were not
reflecting this information the name locally. Now that we have richer
data being stored in the coordinator, we have access to this and when
the sensor updates so will the name.

Author: ScottG489
Commit Message:
Only save selected board ids into config entry

Previously we were saving board and list names in the config and using
this information to set up entities. However, some of this information
can change at run time.

Instead, we get this information from the coordinator and only save the
IDs of the boards the user selected.

Author: ScottG489
Commit Message: Replace string usages for config data keys with constants

Author: ScottG489
Commit Message:
Break out sensor availabilty and name calculation from native_value

I was advised that native_value should not be responsible for handling
the the calculation of these other values, so I've broken them out into
their appropriate methods.

Author: ScottG489
Commit Message:
Replace const defined for integration with preexisting global const

No need for us to define and use our own CONF_API_TOKEN const when this
const is already defined in the project-wide const file.

Author: ScottG489
Commit Message:
Make trello sensor tests more comprehensive

The sensor test is more of an integration test now where it tests the
full setup of the component and asserts on states actually pulled from
the state machine (hass). It also tests updates to the sensors and
ensures errors returned from the trello client are handled properly by
marking the corresponding sensor as unavailable.

This also makes the coordinator tests obsolete, so they have been
removed.

Author: ScottG489
Commit Message:
Fix mypy issue

I believe this issue is due to the fact that the class DeviceInfo moved
packages.

Author: ScottG489
Commit Message:
Remove unnecessary type annotations

Co-authored-by: Joost Lekkerkerker <joostlek@outlook.com>

Author: ScottG489
Commit Message:
Reference locally scoped var rather than member in constructor

Easier to reason about if we're referencing a var scoped locally.

Co-authored-by: Joost Lekkerkerker <joostlek@outlook.com>

Author: ScottG489
Commit Message:
Use attr shorthand where possible

Not necessary to break it out into a property method since we don't
require any extra logic to create the DeviceInfo.

Comment:
@frenck HI thanks for the reminder. I'm quite busy currently, but I will try to fix this. But after over one year to get this integration into Home-Assistant I'm questioning if this PR is the correct way.

Neato and Vorwerk Vacuum cleaners are both based on `pybotvac` and act the same way. The only difference is the authentication flow.
My idea was to just copy the neato integration and fix the authentication flow. But after all the reviews it's a whole new integration that has nothing to do with the neato anymore. 

Please don't get me wrong all review findings were correct and the code is better now. But now it is no longer a fork of the neato integration. It is more a recode of it and that was not my intention when I started this PR.

Maybe it is a better idea to add the Vorwerk-Auth0 authentication to the neato integration. @dshokouhi and @Santober what do you think about this idea? Could you help me?

The ConfigFlow in this PR works for over one year now and I also have a working `pybotvac` patch, where the `PasswordlessSession` is based on the `OAuthSession`, that should work with Home Assistant like the neato `OAuthSession`. 

What I'm not familiar with is the Home Assistant oauth2 token handling. Who could help me with that part?
Author: trunneml

Comment:
Ready for review once again.

---

I've been using a fake device to test the integration: https://github.com/cottsay/aioraven/blob/main/test/mock_device.py

You can set up the device using socat: `sudo socat -d -d pty,raw,echo=0,link=/dev/ttyACM0 "system:python3 test/mock_device.py,pipes"`

It doesn't set the appropriate PID/VID for USB discovery to work, but you can manually add the integration. It was pretty useful for ensuring that the error handling in the integration works as expected.

Comment:
This yields the same string but using a different underlying data type. The function operates on `ListPortInfo` but this code utilizes a `UsbServiceInfo` instance. The field names are the same except the UID/GID, which is stored as a number in the former and a string in the latter.

IMO, designing the a function to deal with both data types would result in more code to do the same task.

Comment: I moved the synchronization logic into the library. I'm not sure I agree that the rest of this code should go there. It's opening the device, getting the list of programmed meters, and getting the type of each of those meters. These are all discrete operations and I don't see much value in lumping them together in the third-party library and breaking the one-to-one relationship between library queries and device messages.

Author: ryanbdclark

Comment:
> Are you able to make this a 3rd party integration as well? At this point the statistical probability of this being merged is fairly slim. PRs get trapped in code review hell from over bearing devs.

I think it would be good for the code owner to make it as a custom integration even just for testing. When I have created custom integrations while I waited for core PRs to get merged, it made testing changes a lot easier, as people could immediately try them out.

But the problem isn't code review hell or over bearing devs. The problem is there are a massive amount of PRs and not enough core devs to handle them, they have to prioritize and letting any code with flaws in will only make more PRs in the future or make PRs more complicated.

on top of that, new integration PRs are the hardest to review because they are so large.

Comment: Don't we want to replace the existing integration and reuse that domain and import the configuration.yaml to the config flow via an import step?
Author: ColinCampbell

Comment:
> Don't we want to replace the existing integration and reuse that domain and import the configuration.yaml to the config flow via an import step?

I think that would be a good idea since I don't think the current one works at all given https://www.home-assistant.io/integrations/decora has 0 installs
Author: ColinCampbell

Comment: Are there examples of integrations that do that? I thought about doing trying to reuse the existing integration. My concern is that at some point between the old integration being written and now, Leviton changed the format of the API key the device firmware expects, and the API key is stored in the old `configuration.yaml` files. Anything ported from the old integration to this new one would need to be re-added or at the very least re-authenticated. That, and the fact that there were 0 installs of the old integration, I wasn't sure that the additional effort to try and port over existing usages would be worth it.
Author: ColinCampbell

Comment:
How does the user get the api key with the old method vs the new method?

Is there a way the old key can be converted into the new format?
Author: ColinCampbell

Comment:
The switch is put into a pairing mode by pressing and hold down on the switch paddle for a few seconds, then the system communicating with it over Bluetooth is able to ask for the API key. As far as I know, there's no conversion method to go from old API keys to new ones. My devices were already on the most recent version of the firmware when I bought them and everything I was able to find about connecting to the devices since the firmware upgrade required repairing the devices.

Edit: happy to defer in terms of actually making a decision on whether this is worth it. I should have time to code something up. This is the first time I've worked in the Home Assistant codebase though so I'm not 100% on what is possible etc
Author: ColinCampbell

Comment:
Maybe import the device data to config entries without validating the api key, and then when the config entry is setup it will fail authentication and a reauth flow can be started which will ask the user to put the device in pairing mode to re-authenticate?

https://developers.home-assistant.io/docs/config_entries_config_flow_handler#reauthentication

You can search for `async_step_import` in the repo for integrations that import data via the config flow to config entries.
Author: ColinCampbell

Comment:
I've started implementing the import and reauth steps! I'm travelling this week so it might be a bit before an update.

Another question, I'm not sure I'll be able to get my device downgraded to past firmware to check that the new bleak-based package I wrote works with previous firmware versions. I can double check the code in communicating with the switches, but is there any prior art and/or hard or soft rules on changing integrations that require upgrading device firmware?
Author: ColinCampbell

Comment:
> I've started implementing the import and reauth steps! I'm travelling this week so it might be a bit before an update.

I've set the PR as draft pending your update. Please don't forget to click the "ready for review" button once you've implemented import of old configurations.

> I can double check the code in communicating with the switches, but is there any prior art and/or hard or soft rules on changing integrations that require upgrading device firmware?

If the firmware us user upgradeable, I don't see any problems with requiring the user to do a firmware upgrade. If you can't test it yourself, I'd suggest to block old firmware already in the config flow if possible, and just ask the user to upgrade the device.

> What about this comment though: [#108326 (comment)](https://github.com/home-assistant/core/pull/108326#discussion_r1599248788), users should not have to reload the integration to make it work. What happens if the automower is out of bluetooth range?

I don't think it's possible to configure the integration if the automower is out of range (it won't / can't be discovered).  
I believe we fixed the issue when it's already configured and out of range at startup, it automatically retries by raising `ConfigEntryNotReady`.

Comment: To answer @joostlek 's question, I followed [this part of the documentation](https://developers.home-assistant.io/docs/integration_fetching_data#separate-polling-for-each-individual-entity). Each device has its own api endpoint so it seemed to make sense to implement it this way.
Author: crevetor

Comment: How do you mean an API endpoint?
Author: crevetor

Comment:
Basically, each devices data is available at `https://api_base/<device_unique_id>/data` which seems to match this sentence in the documentation :

>  If you can map exactly one device endpoint to a single entity, you can fetch the data for this entity inside the update()/async_update() methods
Author: crevetor

Comment: Yes, but that sentence doesn't explain that it should be 1 config entry. I think that would be beneficial. Otherwise with stuff like reauth, you'd have to enter your credentials for every device.
Author: crevetor

We don't allow an option for scan interval. Every integration supporting config entries supports disabling automatic polling and then the user can automate polling manually with the entity service `homeassistant.update_entity.

https://www.home-assistant.io/integrations/homeassistant/#service-homeassistantupdate_entity

Please remove this option.

> The library uses Pydantic and there are 2 things wrong with it:

> 1. The library should declare its dependencies, because now its hoping another integration uses pydantic and it would work. But this can cause issues.
> 2. We are slowly migrating to pydantic v2 ([Pydantic v2 migration issue #99218](https://github.com/home-assistant/core/issues/99218)). Your library seems to use pydantic v2. I personally think we should not merge libraries using V1 without having support for the V2 shims. (checkout the issue for an explanation)
> 
> Also, if you add a `py.typed` file you can get rid of all the `int()`, `str()` and `float()` in `sensor.py`

Comment:
@stefano055415 something went wrong with your merge / rebase, can you try to fix that?

A simple way to recover can be the following flow:
- Update `dev` on your local fork to match upstream
- Rename your local `freedompro` branch to `freedompro_old`
- Create and checkout a new `freedompro` branch off `dev`
- Cherry-pick the relevant commits from `freedompro_old` tp `freedompro`
- Force-push the `freedompro` branch, this PR will then point to the new `freedompro` branch

For the future, this is a good guide for a simple workflow which will always work: https://gist.github.com/Chaser324/ce0505fbed06b947d962

Comment:
@stefano055415 Now it does indeed look fine again 👍

Just a question, should the light work in "optimistic" mode or not?
Optimistic means Home Assistant assumes an attempt to turn on or off the light was successful, and should mainly be used in cases where the device or service doesn't push updates and where it's also not possible to request a state update.

It's preferred to not use optimistic mode when not necessary.

Optimistic:
```py
    async def async_turn_off(self, **kwargs):
        """Async function to set off to light."""
        self._attr_is_on = False
        payload = {"on": False}
        payload = json.dumps(payload)
        await put_state(
            self._session,
            self._api_key,
            self._attr_unique_id,
            payload,
        )
```

Non optimistic:
```py
    async def async_turn_off(self, **kwargs):
        """Async function to set off to light."""
        payload = {"on": False}
        payload = json.dumps(payload)
        await put_state(
            self._session,
            self._api_key,
            self._attr_unique_id,
            payload,
        )
        await self.coordinator.async_request_refresh()
```
Author: stefano055415

Comment:
I think there has been some confusion, even I would prefer to use the non-optimistic version.

From:
```py
async def async_turn_off(self, **kwargs):
        """Async function to set off to light."""
        self._attr_is_on = False
        payload = {"on": False}
        payload = json.dumps(payload)
        await put_state(
            self._session,
            self._api_key,
            self._attr_unique_id,
            payload,
        )
```

To:
```py
 async def async_turn_off(self, **kwargs):
        """Async function to set off to light."""
        payload = {"on": False}
        payload = json.dumps(payload)
        await put_state(
            self._session,
            self._api_key,
            self._attr_unique_id,
            payload,
        )
        await self.coordinator.async_request_refresh()
```

and 

From:

```py
async def async_turn_on(self, **kwargs):
        """Async function to set on to light."""
        self._attr_is_on = True
        payload = {"on": True}
        if ATTR_BRIGHTNESS in kwargs:
            self._attr_brightness = kwargs[ATTR_BRIGHTNESS]
            payload["brightness"] = round(self._attr_brightness / 255 * 100)
        if ATTR_HS_COLOR in kwargs:
            self._attr_hs_color = kwargs[ATTR_HS_COLOR]
            payload["saturation"] = round(self._attr_hs_color[1])
            payload["hue"] = round(self._attr_hs_color[0])
        payload = json.dumps(payload)
        await put_state(
            self._session,
            self._api_key,
            self._attr_unique_id,
            payload,
        )
```

To:

```py
async def async_turn_on(self, **kwargs):
        """Async function to set on to light."""
        payload = {"on": True}
        if ATTR_BRIGHTNESS in kwargs:
            payload["brightness"] = round(kwargs[ATTR_BRIGHTNESS] / 255 * 100)
        if ATTR_HS_COLOR in kwargs:
            payload["saturation"] = round(kwargs[ATTR_HS_COLOR][1])
            payload["hue"] = round(kwargs[ATTR_HS_COLOR][0])
        payload = json.dumps(payload)
        await put_state(
            self._session,
            self._api_key,
            self._attr_unique_id,
            payload,
        )
        await self.coordinator.async_request_refresh()
```

Comment:
Thanks for the review @farmio 

PH changes quite often but not drastically if we check the 2nd decimal point (e.g. 7.21 to 7.22) as electrolysis is a chemical process that naturally raises PH, and this kind of chlorinators have a peristaltic pump that liberates PH reductor in the flow to counter that effect.

I left the 30 seconds interval because it's the default. Coincidentally I sniffed packages in my local network using wireshark to check how often the chlorinator sends updates to the platform and it's around 30 seconds too (unless there's user interaction, in which case it does immediately). I can make it a minute if that's a concern.

However what can change quickly is the state of the binary inputs and relays of the chlorinator, which I removed from this initial PR to comply with the "one platform per pull-request" policy, but as soon as this one is merged I'll open more PRs adding other platforms.

Considering other platforms will be added, maybe 30s is not too much.

The link to my library was correct but I forgot the repo was private. I made it public now.

Comment:
Have you considered not using `DiscoveryService` at all and directly implementing `Listener` here?  It seems like the code can get simpler by inlining some of these calls and just implementing `Listener` in each place you want to listen to an event.

For example, my impression is that `Listener.controller_discovered` is invoked on the first time you add a `Listener`, this you don't need to both loop over the existing found controllers.

This then becomes something like this:
```
async def async_setup_entry(...):
    class InitListener:
        def controller_discovered(self, ctrl: Controller) -> None:
            async_add_entities([ControllerDevice(ctrl)])

  pi_disco = hass.data[PI_DISCO]
  pi_disco.add_listener(InitListener())

```
Author: lazdavila

Comment:
My impression from reading the pescea library is that the `Controller` itself knows about the state change, then it has to notify the `DiscoveryService` which then invokes the `DiscoveryService` in home assistant, which then fires an event that notifies the `ControllerDevice` which compares back with the original `Controller`.

You might find this gets simpler to avoid the global dispatch by having a listener on the `Controller` itself, rather than via the discovery services and notifications. That way a `ControllerDevice` could call `add_listener` on the `Controller` and have fewer comparisons to make.

It also seems like you could also get away with a single event, for what its worth, and just checking the current state of to determine if `_attr_available` needs updating. Having multiple callbacks still results in 3 very similar looking callback methods.

I realize the existing integration this is modeled after does this, but its not clear to me its necessary so i thought i'd suggest these ideas for simplifying further.
Author: lazdavila

Comment:
The most common way this handled seems to be to do all the setup in `async_setup_entry` and tear down in `async_unload_entry` only.  To me this seems more straight forward than having these method methods that store state in `hass.data` which are called from a few places.  I think [gree](https://github.com/home-assistant/core/blob/c68b259bd3e43d77fe9b9d47c768f9aa6198571e/homeassistant/components/gree/__init__.py#L26) is a good example.

As an example, unload happens both from the home assistant stop event and from unloading the config entry and it just makes it a little harder to reason about.

The downside of this is that the config entry and the setup entry do not share the same discovery services, but i think thats ok since config flows are a fairly rare event.  (gree also has a nice interface for initial device discovery in the config flow as well with its `scan` which is nice too fwiw)
Author: lazdavila

Comment:
From a user point of view, it would be interesting if Home assistant would be able to have access to the full P1 meter parameter list, instead of only the limited list this custom component currently offers.
The full parameters are accessible by using the P1-meter API, that delivers the complete telegram, containing all measurements and data the digital meter is capable of.
http://{IP address}/api/v1/telegram
Author: DCSBL

Comment: I would love that, but it would mean that this component needs to parse data from the P1 differently than the other Energy devices (JSON vs raw telegram) which is a bit of a hassle. The support for all entities exposed by JSON is currently in the pipeline by HomeWizard so I think it is not worth it to use the raw telegram data.

Comment:
Hello @Sotolotl,

When attempting to inspect the commits of your pull request for CLA signature status among all authors we encountered commit(s) which were not linked to a GitHub account, thus not allowing us to determine their status(es).

The commits that are missing a linked GitHub account are the following:

- [`c5c2cf143881e8a8521137343e09230edf744cf6`](https://github.com/home-assistant/core/pull/44929/commits/c5c2cf143881e8a8521137343e09230edf744cf6) - This commit has something that looks like an email address (git@billystevenson.co.uk). Maybe try linking that to GitHub?.

Unfortunately, **we are unable to accept this pull request until this situation is corrected.**

Here are your options:

1. If you had an email address set for the commit that simply wasn't linked to your GitHub account you can link that email now and it will retroactively apply to your commits. The simplest way to do this is to click the link to one of the above commits and look for a blue question mark in a blue circle in the top left. Hovering over that bubble will show you what email address you used. Clicking on that button will take you to your email address settings on GitHub. Just add the email address on that page and you're all set. GitHub has more information about this option [in their help center](https://help.github.com/articles/setting-your-email-in-git/#commits-on-github-arent-linking-to-my-account).

2. If you didn't use an email address at all, it was an invalid email, or it's one you can't link to your GitHub, you will need to change the authorship information of the commit and your global Git settings so this doesn't happen again going forward. GitHub provides some great instructions on how to change your authorship information [in their help center](https://help.github.com/articles/setting-your-email-in-git/).
   * If you only made a single commit you should be able to run
      ```
      git commit --amend --author="Author Name <email@address.com>"
      ```
      (substituting Author Name and email@address.com for your actual information) to set the authorship information.
   * If you made more than one commit and the commit with the missing authorship information is not the most recent one you have two options:
       1. You can re-create all commits missing authorship information. This is going to be the easiest solution for developers that aren't extremely confident in their Git and command line skills.
       2. You can use [this script](https://help.github.com/articles/changing-author-info/) that GitHub provides to rewrite history. **Please note:** this should be used only if you are very confident in your abilities and understand its impacts.
   * Whichever method you choose, I will come by to re-check the pull request once you push the fixes to this branch.

We apologize for this inconvenience, especially since it usually bites new contributors to Home Assistant. We hope you understand the need for us to protect ourselves and the great community we all have built legally. The best thing to come out of this is that you only need to fix this once and it benefits the entire Home Assistant and GitHub community.

Thanks, I look forward to checking this PR again soon! :heart:
Author: Sotolotl

Comment:
> I just tried this out, it works great when the probe is just reporting temp, but as soon as I start a cook I get this error:
> 
> `ERROR (MainThread) [homeassistant.components.meater.sensor] Error fetching meater_api data: Error communicating with API: float() argument must be a string or a number, not 'NoneType'`.
> 
> I'm guessing its because some of the variables in `MeaterCook `aren't available at the start of the cook. I was able to fix it by modifying MeaterApi.py to
> 
> ```
> class MeaterCook(object):
>     def __init__(self, id, name, state, target_temp, peak_temp, time_remaining, time_elapsed):
>         self.id = id
>         self.name = name
>         self.state = state
>         if target_temp:
>             self.target_temperature = float(target_temp)
>         if peak_temp:
>             self.peak_temperature = float(peak_temp)
>         if time_remaining:
>             self.time_remaining = int(time_remaining)
>         if time_elapsed:
>             self.time_elapsed = int(time_elapsed)
> ```
> 
> Let me know if you'd like any help!

Ah, that's interesting. I've not seen that issue before but I'll have a play about with it and see if I can reproduce it. I'll update the PyPi library and bump this once I've investigated.

Thanks a lot @brg468 for taking the time to test it out and providing feedback!

Comment:
I'm wondering if you don't want to overwrite this still. `CoordinatorEntity` only provides whether or not the update was successful, but you also have logic in there to see if the probe is still online. Taking this out will change the way the probes are treated when they're offline.  

That's totally up to you, just pointing out that this is different than the way it was before.
Author: Sotolotl

Comment: Yep, missed that!
Author: Sotolotl

Comment: I was thinking about this when I removed it. I wasn't sure it really added any benefit. This code specifically made the devices appear as "unavailable" when they're not connected to Meater Cloud. I know I personally don't like having devices listed as unavailable in my HA install, I almost use it as an impromptu check for stale devices. But that is just my personal preference. Thinking about it now, marking the probe device as unavailable probably is the correct behaviour.
Author: Sotolotl

Comment: I guess my preference would be to keep them as unavailable when they're offline, just because it seems the most accurate way to describe the current state of the entities, but I agree I don't love seeing things marked as unavailable either. Maybe during the review process one of the devs will have a better idea on how to handle it.
Author: Sotolotl

Author: AlePerla
Commit Message:
Use PidfdChildWatcher by default when available (#87951)

This is a backport from cpython 3.12

https://docs.python.org/3/library/asyncio-policy.html
> PidfdChildWatcher is a “Goldilocks” child watcher implementation. It doesn’t require signals or threads, doesn’t interfere with any processes launched outside the event loop, and scales linearly with the number of subprocesses launched by the event loop. The main disadvantage is that pidfds are specific to Linux, and only work on recent (5.3+) kernels.

https://github.com/python/cpython/pull/98024
There are some additional fixes in cpython 3.12
in https://github.com/python/cpython/pull/94184
when there is no event loop running in the main thread
but this is not a problem we have

Author: AlePerla

Unfortunately, **we are unable to accept this pull request until this situation is corrected.**

Here are your options:

1. If you had an email address set for the commit that simply wasn't linked to your GitHub account you can link that email now and it will retroactively apply to your commits. The simplest way to do this is to click the link to one of the above commits and look for a blue question mark in a blue circle in the top left. Hovering over that bubble will show you what email address you used. Clicking on that button will take you to your email address settings on GitHub. Just add the email address on that page and you're all set. GitHub has more information about this option [in their help center](https://help.github.com/articles/setting-your-email-in-git/#commits-on-github-arent-linking-to-my-account).

2. If you didn't use an email address at all, it was an invalid email, or it's one you can't link to your GitHub, you will need to change the authorship information of the commit and your global Git settings so this doesn't happen again going forward. GitHub provides some great instructions on how to change your authorship information [in their help center](https://help.github.com/articles/setting-your-email-in-git/).
   * If you only made a single commit you should be able to run
      ```
      git commit --amend --author="Author Name <email@address.com>"
      ```
      (substituting "Author Name" and "`email@address.com`" for your actual information) to set the authorship information.
   * If you made more than one commit and the commit with the missing authorship information is not the most recent one you have two options:
       1. You can re-create all commits missing authorship information. This is going to be the easiest solution for developers that aren't extremely confident in their Git and command line skills.
       2. You can use [this script](https://help.github.com/articles/changing-author-info/) that GitHub provides to rewrite history. **Please note:** this should be used only if you are very confident in your abilities and understand its impacts.
   * Whichever method you choose, I will come by to re-check the pull request once you push the fixes to this branch.

We apologize for this inconvenience, especially since it usually bites new contributors to Home Assistant. We hope you understand the need for us to protect ourselves and the great community we all have built legally. The best thing to come out of this is that you only need to fix this once and it benefits the entire Home Assistant and GitHub community.

Thanks, I look forward to checking this PR again soon! :heart:

Hi,
integration works perfect. Just two questions:

2. I have a sensor called "Total Production", which shows - since the beginning - 0,2021001 kWh. What is the meaning of this sensor? (btw I don't produce energy)

Nevertheless,

Author: jpbede

Comment:
@derjoerg thanks for testing. 

> 1. I saw that power1-3 are disabled by default, but I see no possibility in the device-config to enable them (I don't have them listed). Is this the intended behaviour?

You should have an option called "+3 hidden entities" under the sensors, if you click on it, it will expand and you will see the 3 disabled entities. If you click on one of it, it will open a modal with additional settings where you can enable it.

![CleanShot 2022-04-07 at 11 30 08](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3989428/162168310-2d9c8c63-e841-43cd-a274-f751f1d9142b.png)

> 2. I have a sensor called "Total Production", which shows - since the beginning - 0,2021001 kWh. What is the meaning of this sensor? (btw I don't produce energy)

Discovergy usually installs a 2-way meter suitable for solar production. Since I cannot distinguish whether you are producing energy or not when the  integration gets activated, the total production sensor is activated by default. You can deactivate it in the same way as you activate a sensor.

Comment:
Hi,

The way dates are returned by the API is not always consistent. I did apply a fix for this in version 0.7.1 of the underlying python package to communicate with the API but did not upgrade the integration to use this updated version.
As a temporary fix, simply change the `requirements_all.txt` file to use `gps-tracker==0.7.1` instead of `gps-tracker==0.7.0` and hopefully it will do the trick.

I will push the fix on this PR this evening when I'll be at home.

Thanks for this report!
Author: ezlo-picori

Comment:
Hi, 

Do you have automatic updates of the location working? I didn't get them (or I was not patient enough - maybe there's a refresh timeout?). 
I resolved it for myself by adding an automation that reloads the integration every three minutes. Although that does give me the most recent location quite speedily, the downside is that for some reason the location always goes "unavailable" during this process":

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6883926/177041597-6b4bd796-8cfa-470f-9060-dd4fc2f100fe.png)
Author: ezlo-picori

Comment:
Hi,

The location should be automatically updated every 4 minutes.
You can change this delay in [device_tracker.py](https://github.com/home-assistant/core/pull/63671/files#diff-9beb93535c8b2327b9b4e5ae2421333877fcd0d92a80c25af4e15c91e97b19d5R22) but do not make it too low, one should not spam Invoxia API with too frequent requests.

If it does not work, I'll look into that when I am back at home next week.

@VederJay Finally I too faced polling issues.

Hi,
To use an integration as a custom_component, you must add a `version` item in `manifest.json`, I guess you forgot that step?
Otherwise, I have no idea...

You may also take a look to https://github.com/timothyle97/Invoxia-HA : @timothyle97 converted this pull request into a custom_component that you may directly copy into your home-assistant instance. See [here](https://github.com/timothyle97/Invoxia-HA/blob/main/custom_components/invoxia/manifest.json#L13) in particular if you need an example for the `manifest.json` tweaking.

Unfortunately, I have lost hope about this PR being accepted one day so using a custom component might be the best approach...

Author: jeeftor

Comment:
You might want to disable wind speed and wind direction by default as they are updated 20 times per minute. The wind average and wind direction average are updated once per minute like the other sensors.

*Edit: corrected typo*
Author: jeeftor

Comment:
> You might want to disable wind speed and wind direction by default as they are updated 20 times per second. The wind average and wind direction average are updated once per minute like the other sensors.

It's actually around 20 times per minute (every 3 seconds). While still frequent, I would argue that it's one of the more relevant sensors.
Author: jeeftor

Comment:
> It's actually around 20 times per minute (every 3 seconds). While still frequent, I would argue that it's one of the more relevant sensors.

Oops, typo. Corrected. Thanks for catching. But it's still a valid question as those two sensors accounted for around half of all data in my HA database.
Author: jeeftor

Comment:
> > It's actually around 20 times per minute (every 3 seconds). While still frequent, I would argue that it's one of the more relevant sensors.
> 
> Oops, typo. Corrected. Thanks for catching. But it's still a valid question as those two sensors accounted for around half of all data in my HA database.

Yeah, agreed. Wind direction for me is less relevant. But wind speed is crucial. Sometimes a minute delay is too long and can cause serious damage. I get frequent wind which can spike very quickly. Being able to react to the first such spike is important as a full minute of sustained high winds can be disastrous. I guess the question is, should it be disabled by default with a note saying to enable it if you need it. Or should it be enabled by default with a note saying it may cause a large HA database and disable if unneeded?
Author: jeeftor

Comment:
> But wind speed is crucial. Sometimes a minute delay is too long and can cause serious damage. I get frequent wind which can spike very quickly. Being able to react to the first such spike is important as a full minute of sustained high winds can be disastrous.

It would be nice to be able to use the data for automations without being stored. Or maybe have a different retention period.

Comment:
> It would be nice to be able to use the data for automations without being stored. Or maybe have a different retention period.

I found that it's possible to prevent recording selected values. This leaves them available to use for automations.

```
# https://www.home-assistant.io/integrations/recorder/
recorder:
  exclude:
    entity_globs:
      - sensor.outdoor_wind_speed
      - sensor.outdoor_wind_direction
```

Comment:
I guess it could be, however, the most common case is that an individual will have a **single** weatherflow device in their house which is sending out **UDP** packets on the local network. Being that its **UDP** we don't need to actually know the IP address of the Weatherflow device and we will be using a value of  `0.0.0.0` for `CONF_HOST` which is actually better described as a host filter rather than a specific host we are getting data from ... and in this case just saying `Weatherflow` I believe is clearer than `Weatherflow 0.0.0.0`

We have two options:
- UPD Traffic from a single specific IP
- UPD traffic from anywhere (this is a much easier setup case because if your weatherflow device changes DHCP it will still wokr)

Comment:
Let's take air temp as example.
Let's say the device sends the information as 70 F and you have configured the sensor to be natively using F as unit.
Then HA will convert it for a metric user by itself to 21 C.
Now you're doing all kind of conversions to do that for the user when it should not be needed (HA will take care + the user can always change after).

Or can the device send different depending on the setting so you assume it's configured same as their HA? Can we then check that instead?
Author: jeeftor

Comment:
So internally the backing library is using the pint class which has a ton of internal conversions: https://pint.readthedocs.io/en/stable/user/nonmult.html Some of the sensor values are coming in in "non-ha-supported" units in some cases. We aren't actually ALWAYS doing the conversion. In the case of any Temp sensors, however, we are not applying ANY conversion ... (as I hope to show) ```python @dataclass class WeatherFlowTemperatureSensorEntityDescription(WeatherFlowSensorEntityDescription): """Describes a WeatherFlow temperature sensor entity description.""" def __post_init__(self) -> None: """Post initialisation processing.""" self.native_unit_of_measurement = UnitOfTemperature.CELSIUS self.device_class = SensorDeviceClass.TEMPERATURE self.state_class = SensorStateClass.MEASUREMENT self.decimals = 1 ``` This will just pull in the native `c` value off the sensor. I've rewritten the code a little bit to maybe make it more clearer. So when we are in `def native_value(self) -> datetime | StateType:` ```python # Extract raw sensor data raw_sensor_data = getattr( self.device, self.entity_description.key if self.entity_description.attr is None else self.entity_description.attr, ) ``` We get a Quantity & units value. ![image](https://github.com/home-assistant/core/assets/6491743/33de67fa-6487-4737-ab20-749de391f49b) Temperature sensors utilize HA conversion -> so it doesn't jump into the conversion block at all. ![image](https://github.com/home-assistant/core/assets/6491743/2b4c6bfe-ed35-479b-927a-52f070a02045) In the next block it will just extract the sensor value and round it accordingly: ```python if isinstance(noramlized_sensor_data, Quantity): sensor_value = noramlized_sensor_data.magnitude if (decimals := self.entity_description.decimals) is not None: sensor_value = round(sensor_value, decimals) return sensor_value ``` So it's just skipping over the logic (even though it is called) - and then all we are doing is parsing out the `sensor_value` and applying a rounding factor.
The few cases it does need to apply conversions is when its using Non-hA supported units in say `Air_Density` Home Assistant natively doesn't support the values in question: ![image](https://github.com/home-assistant/core/assets/6491743/d706d987-7101-4069-af4f-8f08a998dbf6) So for this value ![image](https://github.com/home-assistant/core/assets/6491743/d84c290f-98e6-4415-99f4-298516a1becb) There is a conversion function which is applied - the native HA ones won't cut it ... (I made a few rewrites after writing this to update variable names for clarity) ... happy to remove them and go back to the simpler version if you prefer but hopefully this explains some of the logic better. In summary: -> We don't really have to do this that often, but sometimes its needed on the sensors... It still takes advantage of the Native HA conversion when possible (like the temp example) where it will store the value in native in C allowing HA to handle the F conversion
Author: jeeftor

Comment:
@chamberlain2007 The problem is that it's misleading and confusing to derive a class from `DataUpdateCoordinator` and then go ahead and not use a single functionality of that class except for `async_add_listener`.

What you could do instead is to derive your coordinator from `BaseDataUpdateCoordinatorProtocol` and your entities from `BaseCoordinatorEntity`.
Author: chamberlain2007

Comment:

> 
> What you could do instead is to derive your coordinator from `BaseDataUpdateCoordinatorProtocol` and your entities from `BaseCoordinatorEntity`.

Comment:
Apologies for the 11th hour request. 

I noticed that the ‘humidifier’ entity isn’t being used for the Humidifier or Dehumidifier integrations. And the ‘weather’ entity isn’t being used for the outside temp and humidity sensors. The Ecobee integration is a great example of both integrations. 

It would be great if these were added in for the initial release, or at the very least a fast follow to reduce as many migrations as possible farther down the line. @chamberlain2007 

Other integrations such as Aux/Emergency heat can be added in later without worrying about migration of entities later.

> 
> Other integrations such as Aux/Emergency heat can be added in later without worrying about migration of entities later.

The Home Assistant team prefers starting an integration with a minimal set of functionality, hence this only containing the climate entity. If you use the other entities, I would recommend staying with the unofficial version until everything is implemented here.
